column2: CHAPTER XXII.

column2: THEY swarmed up towards Sherburn's house, a-whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see.
column3: THEY swarmed up towards Sherburn's house, a whooping and raging like Injuns, and everything had to clear the way or get run over and tromped to mush, and it was awful to see.

column2: Children was heeling it ahead of the mob, screaming and trying to get out of the way; and every window along the road was full of women's heads, and there was nigger boys in every tree, and bucks and wenches looking over every fence; and as soon as the mob would get nearly to them they would break and skaddle back out of reach.

column2: It's amusing.

column3: The idea of you thinking you had pluck enough to lynch a underscore man underscore!

column2: Because you're brave enough to tar and feather poor friendless cast-out women that come along here, did that make you think you had grit enough to lay your hands on a _man_?
column3: Because you're brave enough to tar and feather poor friendless cast out women that come along here, did that make you think you had grit enough to lay your hands on a underscore man underscore?

column2: Why, a _man's_ safe in the hands of ten thousand of your kindas long as it's daytime and you're not behind him.

column2: Do I know you?	Do I know you?

column2: I know you clear through.
column3: I know you clear through.

column2: I was born and raised in the South, and I've lived in the North; so I know the average all around. The average man's a coward.
column3: I was born and raised in the South, and I've lived in the North; so I know the average all around. The average man's a coward.

column2: In the North he lets anybody walk over him that wants to, and goes home and prays for a humble spirit to bear it. In the South one man all by himself, has stopped a stage full of men in the daytime, and robbed the lot.
column3: In the North he lets anybody walk over him that wants to, and goes home and prays for a humble spirit to bear it. In the South one man all by himself, has stopped a stage full of men in the daytime, and robbed the lot.

column2: Your newspapers call you a brave people so much that you think you are braver than any other peoplewhereas you're just _as_ brave, and no braver.
column3: Your newspapers call you a brave people so much that you think you are braver than any other people  whereas you're just underscore as underscore brave, and no braver.

column2: Why don't your juries hang murderers?
column3: Why don't your juries hang murderers?

column2: Because they're afraid the man's friends will shoot them in the back, in the darkand it's just what they _would_ do.

column2: Your mistake is, that you didn't bring a man with you; that's one mistake, and the other is that you didn't come in the dark and fetch your masks.
column3: Your mistake is, that you didn't bring a man with you; that's one mistake, and the other is that you didn't come in the dark and fetch your masks.

column2: You brought _part_ of a manBuck Harkness, thereand if you hadn't had him to start you, you'd a taken it out in blowing.

column2: The average man don't like trouble and danger.

column2: _You_ don't like trouble and danger.

column2: But if only _half_ a manlike Buck Harkness, thereshouts 'Lynch him! lynch him!' you're afraid to back downafraid you'll be found out to be what you are_cowards_and so you raise a yell, and hang yourselves on to that half-a-man's coat-tail, and come raging up here, swearing what big things you're going to do.

column2: The pitifulest thing out is a mob; that's what an army isa mob; they don't fight with courage that's born in them, but with courage that's borrowed from their mass, and from their officers.
column3: The pitifulest thing out is a mob; that's what an army is  a mob; they don't fight with courage that's born in them, but with courage that's borrowed from their mass, and from their officers.

column2: But a mob without any _man_ at the head of it is _beneath_ pitifulness.

column2: Now the thing for _you_ to do is to droop your tails and go home and crawl in a hole.
column3: Now the thing for underscore you underscore to do is to droop your tails and go home and crawl in a hole.

column2: If any real lynching's going to be done it will be done in the dark, Southern fashion; and when they come they'll bring their masks, and fetch a _man_ along.
column3: If any real lynching's going to be done it will be done in the dark, Southern fashion; and when they come they'll bring their masks, and fetch a underscore man underscore along.

column2: The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness he heeled it after them, looking tolerable cheap.
column3: The crowd washed back sudden, and then broke all apart, and went tearing off every which way, and Buck Harkness he heeled it after them, looking tolerable cheap.

column2: I could a stayed if I wanted to, but I didn't want to.
column3: I could a stayed if I wanted to, but I didn't want to.

column2: I went to the circus and loafed around the back side till the watchman went by, and then dived in under the tent.
column3: I went to the circus and loafed around the back side till the watchman went by, and then dived in under the tent.

column2: I had my twenty-dollar gold piece and some other money, but I reckoned I better save it, because there ain't no telling how soon you are going to need it, away from home and amongst strangers that way.
column3: I had my twenty dollar gold piece and some other money, but I reckoned I better save it, because there ain't no telling how soon you are going to need it, away from home and amongst strangers that way.

column2: You can't be too careful.
column3: You can't be too careful.

column2: I ain't opposed to spending money on circuses when there ain't no other way, but there ain't no use in _wasting_ it on them.
column3: I ain't opposed to spending money on circuses when there ain't no other way, but there ain't no use in underscore wasting underscore it on them.

column2: It was a real bully circus.
column3: It was a real bully circus.

column2: It was the splendidest sight that ever was when they all come riding in, two and two, a gentleman and lady, side by side, the men just in their drawers and undershirts, and no shoes nor stirrups, and resting their hands on their thighs easy and comfortablethere must a been twenty of themand every lady with a lovely complexion, and perfectly beautiful, and looking just like a gang of real sure-enough queens, and dressed in clothes that cost millions of dollars, and just littered with diamonds.
column3: It was the splendidest sight that ever was when they all come riding in, two and two, a gentleman and lady, side by side, the men just in their drawers and undershirts, and no shoes nor stirrups, and resting their hands on their thighs easy and comfortable  there must a been twenty of them  and every lady with a lovely complexion, and perfectly beautiful, and looking just like a gang of real sure enough queens, and dressed in clothes that cost millions of dollars, and just littered with diamonds.

column2: It was a powerful fine sight; I never see anything so lovely.
column3: It was a powerful fine sight; I never see anything so lovely.

column2: And then one by one they got up and stood, and went a-weaving around the ring so gentle and wavy and graceful, the men looking ever so tall and airy and straight, with their heads bobbing and skimming along, away up there under the tent-roof, and every lady's rose-leafy dress flapping soft and silky around her hips, and she looking like the most loveliest parasol.
column3: And then one by one they got up and stood, and went a weaving around the ring so gentle and wavy and graceful, the men looking ever so tall and airy and straight, with their heads bobbing and skimming along, away up there under the tent roof, and every lady's rose leafy dress flapping soft and silky around her hips, and she looking like the most loveliest parasol.

column2: And then faster and faster they went, all of them dancing, first one foot out in the air and then the other, the horses leaning more and more, and the ringmaster going round and round the center-pole, cracking his whip and shouting "Hi!hi!" and the clown cracking jokes behind him; and by and by all hands dropped the reins, and every lady put her knuckles on her hips and every gentleman folded his arms, and then how the horses did lean over and hump themselves!
column3: And then faster and faster they went, all of them dancing, first one foot out in the air and then the other, the horses leaning more and more, and the ringmaster going round and round the center pole, cracking his whip and shouting "Hi!  hi!" and the clown cracking jokes behind him; and by and by all hands dropped the reins, and every lady put her knuckles on her hips and every gentleman folded his arms, and then how the horses did lean over and hump themselves!

column2: And so one after the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands and went just about wild.
column3: And so one after the other they all skipped off into the ring, and made the sweetest bow I ever see, and then scampered out, and everybody clapped their hands and went just about wild.

column2: Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people.
column3: Well, all through the circus they done the most astonishing things; and all the time that clown carried on so it most killed the people.

column2: The ringmaster couldn't ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever _could_ think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I couldn't noway understand.
column3: The ringmaster couldn't ever say a word to him but he was back at him quick as a wink with the funniest things a body ever said; and how he ever underscore could underscore think of so many of them, and so sudden and so pat, was what I couldn't noway understand.

column2: Why, I couldn't a thought of them in a year. And by and by a drunk man tried to get into the ringsaid he wanted to ride; said he could ride as well as anybody that ever was.
column3: Why, I couldn't a thought of them in a year. And by and by a drunk man tried to get into the ring  said he wanted to ride; said he could ride as well as anybody that ever was.

column2: They argued and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn't listen, and the whole show come to a standstill.
column3: They argued and tried to keep him out, but he wouldn't listen, and the whole show come to a standstill.

column2: Then the people begun to holler at him and make fun of him, and that made him mad, and he begun to rip and tear; so that stirred up the people, and a lot of men begun to pile down off of the benches and swarm towards the ring, saying, "Knock him down! throw him out!" and one or two women begun to scream.
column3: Then the people begun to holler at him and make fun of him, and that made him mad, and he begun to rip and tear; so that stirred up the people, and a lot of men begun to pile down off of the benches and swarm towards the ring, saying, "Knock him down! throw him out!" and one or two women begun to scream.

column2: So, then, the ringmaster he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn't be no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn't make no more trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse. So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on.
column3: So, then, the ringmaster he made a little speech, and said he hoped there wouldn't be no disturbance, and if the man would promise he wouldn't make no more trouble he would let him ride if he thought he could stay on the horse. So everybody laughed and said all right, and the man got on.

column2: The minute he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around, with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and laughing till tears rolled down.
column3: The minute he was on, the horse begun to rip and tear and jump and cavort around, with two circus men hanging on to his bridle trying to hold him, and the drunk man hanging on to his neck, and his heels flying in the air every jump, and the whole crowd of people standing up shouting and laughing till tears rolled down.

column2: And at last, sure enough, all the circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground on one side, and then t'other one on t'other side, and the people just crazy.
column3: And at last, sure enough, all the circus men could do, the horse broke loose, and away he went like the very nation, round and round the ring, with that sot laying down on him and hanging to his neck, with first one leg hanging most to the ground on one side, and then t'other one on t'other side, and the people just crazy.

column2: It warn't funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his danger. But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the bridle, a-reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up and dropped the bridle and stood! and the horse a-going like a house afire too.
column3: It warn't funny to me, though; I was all of a tremble to see his danger. But pretty soon he struggled up astraddle and grabbed the bridle, a reeling this way and that; and the next minute he sprung up and dropped the bridle and stood! and the horse a going like a house afire too.

column2: He just stood up there, a-sailing around as easy and comfortable as if he warn't ever drunk in his lifeand then he begun to pull off his clothes and sling them.

column3: He shed them so thick they kind of clogged up the air, and altogether he shed seventeen suits.

column2: And, then, there he was, slim and handsome, and dressed the gaudiest and prettiest you ever saw, and he lit into that horse with his whip and made him fairly humand finally skipped off, and made his bow and danced off to the dressing-room, and everybody just a-howling with pleasure and astonishment.

column2: Then the ringmaster he see how he had been fooled, and he _was_ the sickest ringmaster you ever see, I reckon.

column2: WELL, all day him and the king was hard at it, rigging up a stage and a curtain and a row of candles for footlights; and that night the house was jam full of men in no time.
column3: WELL, all day him and the king was hard at it, rigging up a stage and a curtain and a row of candles for footlights; and that night the house was jam full of men in no time.

column2: When the place couldn't hold no more, the duke he quit tending door and went around the back way and come on to the stage and stood up before the curtain and made a little speech, and praised up this tragedy, and said it was the most thrillingest one that ever was; and so he went on a-bragging about the tragedy, and about Edmund Kean the Elder, which was to play the main principal part in it; and at last when he'd got everybody's expectations up high enough, he rolled up the curtain, and the next minute the king come a-prancing out on all fours, naked; and he was painted all over, ring-streaked-and-striped, all sorts of colors, as splendid as a rainbow.
